The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

Let $G$ be a group and $X$ a set. An action or an operation of $G$ on $X$ is a map $G \times X \longrightarrow X, \quad(g, x) \longmapsto g \cdot x$ such that: (i) $1 \cdot x=x$ for the unit element $1 \in G$ and for elements $x \in X$. (ii) $(g h) \cdot x=g \cdot(h \cdot x)$ for $g, h \in G, x \in X$.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Group Action to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To determine if the concept of a domain is necessary for the definition of a group action to make sense, we need to analyze the components of the group action definition. A group action involves a map from the Cartesian product $G 	imes X$ to $X$, where $G$ is a group and $X$ is a set. This map, denoted as $(g, x) \mapsto g \cdot x$, must satisfy certain properties. 

The concept of a domain in mathematics refers to the set of all possible input values for which a function is defined. In the context of a group action, the domain of the map is $G 	imes X$. This is crucial because the definition of the group action explicitly involves a function (the map) from $G 	imes X$ to $X$. Without understanding what a domain is (i.e., the set of inputs over which the function is defined), one cannot fully grasp the concept of a function or a map, which is central to the definition of a group action. 

Therefore, the concept of a domain is necessary to understand and define a group action, as it specifies the inputs over which the group action (function) operates.
